title: 109_s3559
content: The Act titled "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" enhances penalties for fraud related to major disaster or emergency benefits. The Act "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" increases penalties for fraud involving major disaster or emergency benefits by adding a new section to Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code. This new section, titled "Fraud in connection with major disaster or emergency benefits," outlines specific actions that constitute fraud in such circumstances. The Act "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" increases penalties for fraud involving major disaster or emergency benefits by adding a new section to Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code. This new section outlines specific actions that constitute fraud in connection with major disaster or emergency benefits, including making false statements or representations in any matter involving benefits authorized under disaster relief acts or related to procurement of property or services in emergency or disaster declarations. Contractors working with the United States may face fines or imprisonment for up to 30 years if involved in fraud related to disaster assistance benefits. The fraud must involve interstate or foreign commerce or the use of mail services. Contractors working with the United States may face fines or imprisonment for up to 30 years if involved in fraud related to disaster assistance benefits, which includes the transportation, transmission, or payment of such benefits. The term 'benefit' refers to any form of value provided by the government or other entities. Increased criminal penalties for wire, radio, and television fraud during a presidentially declared major disaster or emergency are outlined in Section 1343 of title 18, United States Code. This includes fraud related to benefits authorized, transported, transmitted, transferred, disbursed, or paid in connection with the disaster or emergency. SEC. 4 amends Section 1341 of title 18, United States Code to increase criminal penalties for engaging in mail fraud during a presidentially declared major disaster or emergency. It includes fraud related to benefits authorized, transported, transmitted, transferred, disbursed, or paid in connection with the disaster or emergency. The United States Sentencing Commission must promptly amend sentencing guidelines to increase penalties for fraud or theft related to major disaster or emergency declarations. An explanation of these actions must be submitted to the Judiciary Committees of Congress. The Sentencing Commission must amend sentencing guidelines to increase penalties for fraud or theft related to major disaster or emergency declarations. They must also submit an explanation of these actions to the Judiciary Committees of Congress. The Sentencing Commission must amend sentencing guidelines to address fraud or theft related to major disaster or emergency declarations. This includes the need for aggressive law enforcement action, consistency with other directives, consideration of circumstances for exceptions, necessary changes to guidelines, and alignment with the purposes of sentencing. The Sentencing Commission must promptly amend guidelines to address fraud or theft related to major disasters or emergencies, ensuring alignment with sentencing purposes under section 3553(a)(2) of title 18, US Code. The Commission has emergency authority to enact these guidelines within 30 days of the enactment of the Act.
